templates.name: Complete Su-Field
templates.description: A basic Su-Field system with two substances and a field
examples: A hammer (S1) striking a nail (S2) through mechanical force (F)
A motor (S1) powering a fan (S2) through electrical energy (F)
A medicine (S1) treating an illness (S2) through chemical action (F)

templates.name: Incomplete Su-Field
templates.description: A system missing either a substance or field
examples: A device (S1) that needs to be connected to power source (missing F) to affect an object (S2)
A tool (S1) that needs an energy source (missing F) to work on a material (S2)
A patient (S2) needing a treatment (missing S1) delivered via some method (missing F)

templates.name: Harmful Su-Field
templates.description: A Su-Field system with harmful interaction
examples: Friction (F) between moving parts (S1, S2) causing wear
Radiation (F) damaging living tissue (S2) from a radiation source (S1)
Electromagnetic interference (F) from a device (S1) disrupting another device (S2)

templates.name: Insufficient Su-Field
templates.description: A Su-Field system with insufficient interaction
examples: Weak signal (F) from a transmitter (S1) not reaching a receiver (S2) properly
Insufficient heat (F) from a heater (S1) failing to warm a room (S2) adequately
Weak adhesive bond (F) between two surfaces (S1, S2) failing to hold them together

templates.name: Chain Su-Field
templates.description: A chain of Su-Field systems
examples: A remote control (S1) sending a signal (F1) to a receiver (S2), which controls a device (S3) via electrical signals (F2)
A doctor (S1) giving instructions (F1) to a nurse (S2), who administers medicine (F2) to a patient (S3)
A computer (S1) sending data (F1) to a printer controller (S2), which controls print mechanisms (F2) to create an image (S3)

templates.name: Double Su-Field
templates.description: A system with two fields acting on the same substances
examples: A material (S1) bonded to another (S2) using both adhesive (F1) and mechanical fasteners (F2)
A teacher (S1) educating students (S2) through both visual aids (F1) and verbal explanation (F2)
A medication (S1) affecting a condition (S2) through both chemical (F1) and thermal (F2) effects

templates.name: Complex Su-Field
templates.description: A system with multiple substances and fields with complex interactions
examples: An ecosystem with multiple species interacting through different relationships
A complex manufacturing system with multiple machines, materials, and energy flows
A healthcare system with multiple practitioners, patients, treatments, and information flows

templates.name: Controlled Su-Field
templates.description: A system where a third substance controls the interaction
examples: A thermostat (S3) controlling the heat flow (F1) from a heater (S1) to a room (S2) using electrical signals (F2)
A valve (S3) controlling the flow of fluid (F1) from a reservoir (S1) to a container (S2) using mechanical force (F2)
A regulator (S3) controlling the electrical current (F1) from a power source (S1) to a device (S2)

templates.name: Field-Transforming Su-Field
templates.description: A system where one substance transforms one field into another
examples: A solar panel (S3) converting light energy (F1) from the sun (S1) into electrical energy (F2) for a device (S2)
A microphone (S3) converting sound waves (F1) from a source (S1) into electrical signals (F2) for an amplifier (S2)
A transducer (S3) converting one form of energy (F1) from a source (S1) into another form (F2) for a receiver (S2)

templates.name: Self-Regulating Su-Field
templates.description: A system that adjusts its own operation based on feedback
examples: A cruise control system with speed sensor feedback and automatic adjustment
A living organism with homeostatic mechanisms
A self-adjusting manufacturing system with quality control feedback

templates.name: Quantum Su-Field
templates.description: A system involving quantum effects and interactions
examples: Quantum computers using entangled qubits
Quantum sensors detecting microscopic changes through quantum effects
Quantum communication systems using entangled particles

templates.name: Nano-Scale Su-Field
templates.description: A system with nanoscale components and interactions
examples: Drug delivery nanoparticles interacting with target cells
Nanoscale sensors detecting molecular changes
Nanorobots performing targeted operations in a system

templates.name: Bio-Inspired Su-Field
templates.description: A system based on biological principles and interactions
examples: Biomimetic materials that self-heal like biological tissues
Swarm robotics systems inspired by insect colonies
Artificial neural networks modeled after brain function

templates.name: Smart Material Su-Field
templates.description: A system using materials that respond to environmental changes
examples: Shape memory alloys changing form in response to temperature
Photochromic materials darkening in response to UV light
Piezoelectric materials generating electricity when compressed

templates.name: AI-Enhanced Su-Field
templates.description: A system where artificial intelligence optimizes interactions
examples: Smart manufacturing systems with AI optimization
AI-controlled energy grids balancing supply and demand
Autonomous vehicles with AI decision-making for navigation

templates.name: Distributed Su-Field
templates.description: A system with distributed components and interactions across space
examples: Internet of Things sensor networks
Distributed computing systems
Smart city infrastructure with interconnected systems

templates.name: Temporal Su-Field
templates.description: A system with time-dependent or asynchronous interactions
examples: Time-release drug delivery systems
Delayed-action mechanisms in devices
Scheduled maintenance systems that operate at specific intervals

templates.name: Multi-Modal Su-Field
templates.description: A system integrating multiple sensory or data modalities
examples: Virtual reality systems with visual, audio, and haptic feedback
Multi-modal medical diagnostics using different imaging techniques
Assistive technologies combining different sensory inputs and outputs

templates.name: Emergent Su-Field
templates.description: A system where new properties emerge from component interactions
examples: Neural networks with emergent pattern recognition
Complex adaptive systems with emergent behaviors
Social networks with emergent trends and phenomena

templates.name: Field-Field Interaction
templates.description: A system where fields interact with each other
examples: Interference patterns in wave physics
Electromagnetic field interactions in antennas
Combined force fields in physics simulations
